perturbation.original_text: 3.6.1 All payments shall be made by bank transfer to such account as may be indicated by Dexcel, Dexcel and Kitov each bearing their own bank transfer costs, net thirty (30) days from Delivery. All payments shall be made in U.S. Dollars.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.6.1 All payments shall be made by bank transfer to such account as may be indicated by Dexcel, Dexcel and Kitov each bearing their own bank transfer costs, net sixty (60) days from Delivery. All payments shall be made in U.S. Dollars.
perturbation.explanation: Changing the payment terms to net 60 days may conflict with standard commercial practices and prompt payment laws in some jurisdictions (including within the United States and Israel). Many jurisdictions have laws mandating payment within 30 days, especially for smaller businesses. This alteration introduces a potential legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Prompt Payment Laws (Vary by state/country; e.g., Prompt Payment Act in the US, Late Payment of Commercial Debts Regulations in the UK).

perturbation.original_text: 3.7.2 Kitov shall provide Dexcel with written notification of any shortfalls in shipment quantity, and (a) any out-of-specification temperature excursions based on the downloaded data logger information following compliance with the provisions of the Quality Agreement, and/or (b) any failure of the Product to meet the Specifications which are apparent upon visual inspection and/or identification testing of the Product delivered to it by Dexcel (each of (a) and (b) being an "Apparent Defect"), such notification to be provided within thirty (30) Working Days of receipt of the Product at Kitov's warehouse, accompanied by samples of any such allegedly defective Product and any such Product shall not be removed from quarantine until their status is resolved. In the event that a defect is not apparent upon visual inspection during the shelf life of the Product ("Hidden Defect"), Kitov shall use commercially reasonably best efforts to provide Dexcel with written notification within thirty (30) Working Days of discovering the same, to be accompanied by samples of any such allegedly defective Product, if such samples are available In the event of any failure by Kitov to provide Dexcel with written notification of any such shortfall, Apparent Defect or Hidden Defect within the respective aforementioned periods, it shall be deemed as Kitov having accepted the relevant consignment.
perturbation.changed_text: 3.7.2 Kitov shall provide Dexcel with written notification of any shortfalls in shipment quantity, and (a) any out-of-specification temperature excursions based on the downloaded data logger information following compliance with the provisions of the Quality Agreement, and/or (b) any failure of the Product to meet the Specifications which are apparent upon visual inspection and/or identification testing of the Product delivered to it by Dexcel (each of (a) and (b) being an "Apparent Defect"), such notification to be provided within ten (10) Working Days of receipt of the Product at Kitov's warehouse, accompanied by samples of any such allegedly defective Product and any such Product shall not be removed from quarantine until their status is resolved. In the event that a defect is not apparent upon visual inspection during the shelf life of the Product ("Hidden Defect"), Kitov shall use commercially reasonably best efforts to provide Dexcel with written notification within ten (10) Working Days of discovering the same, to be accompanied by samples of any such allegedly defective Product, if such samples are available In the event of any failure by Kitov to provide Dexcel with written notification of any such shortfall, Apparent Defect or Hidden Defect within the respective aforementioned periods, it shall be deemed as Kitov having accepted the relevant consignment.
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the notification period for apparent and hidden defects from 30 to 10 working days is likely to be considered unreasonably short under the Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) as adopted by many US states, or similar regulations in Israel for international transactions. The UCC requires a 'reasonable time' for inspection and rejection, and 10 days is likely insufficient for complex pharmaceutical products, particularly when 'hidden defects' are involved. Therefore, this creates a potential legal contradiction.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Uniform Commercial Code (UCC) - Section 2-602 and 2-606 regarding reasonable time for inspection and acceptance/rejection of goods.

perturbation.original_text: 5.2.2 in the event that a Party is in material breach of this Agreement or the Quality Agreement and fails to remedy such breach within thirty (30) calendar days from receipt of written notification of same, by the non-breaching Party;
perturbation.changed_text: 5.2.2 in the event that a Party is in material breach of this Agreement or the Quality Agreement and fails to remedy such breach within ten (10) calendar days from receipt of written notification of same, by the non-breaching Party;
perturbation.explanation: Reducing the cure period for a material breach from 30 to 10 calendar days may be considered commercially unreasonable, especially for complex manufacturing agreements. Courts often consider the nature of the breach, the effort required to cure it, and industry standards when evaluating the reasonableness of a cure period. This change could be deemed unconscionable or against public policy, potentially conflicting with contract law principles related to good faith and fair dealing.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Principles of good faith and fair dealing, unconscionability doctrines. Varies by jurisdiction, but broadly applicable in contract law.
